Stem: Alpha Standardized Science G6.1 Created By STC Account Water Cycle Use the diagram to answer the question below What happens during evaporation?
Choices: A) source region is that region of the Earth's surface where large masses of air have a uniform temperature and water vapor content. There are three main categories of source regions: 1) Arctic; air masses occurring over arctic regions which are cold 2) Polar; air masses occurring away from the poles which are cold 3) Tropical; air masses occurring in the tropics which are hot Air masses are represented by 'c' for continental and 'm' for maritime, and the source regions are represented by 'A' for arctic, 'P' for polar. And 'T' for tropical. Each source region can also be either continental or maritime. To show this, category letters are usually combined. So, there are a total of six types of air masses: maritime arctic (mA), maritime polar (mP), maritime tropical (mT), continental arctic (cA), continental polar (cP), continental tropical (cT). Continental air mass in antarctic region is termed as continental antarctic and represented as cAA. The image shows different source regions on Earth: What type of weather would a continental tropical air mass, such as those originating from the Sonoran and, B) Water falls on the surface, C) Water converts into droplets, D) Water infiltrates under the ground Answer the following questions after reading this passage. Air Masses Air mass is defined as the volume of air which can be either hot or cold and moist or dry depending on its water vapor content. Air masses control the weather of a region. The two main categories of air masses are continental and maritime. An air mass found over land is called continental and one found over water is called maritime. Air over continents are dry and air over oceans are moist (or wet).

Stem: There are three main categories of source regions: 1) Arctic; air masses occurring over arctic regions which are cold 2) Polar; air masses occurring away from the poles which are cold 3) Tropical; air masses occurring in the tropics which are hot Air masses are represented by 'c' for continental and 'm' for maritime, and the source regions are represented by 'A' for arctic, 'P' for polar. And 'T' for tropical. Each source region can also be either continental or maritime. To show this, category letters are usually combined. So, there are a total of six types of air masses: maritime arctic (mA), maritime polar (mP), maritime tropical (mT), continental arctic (cA), continental polar (cP), continental tropical (cT). Stem: The Seafoam Reef Marine Conservation Committee is evaluating two proposals to protect the declining coral reef ecosystem. Scientific data shows that boat anchors have damaged 40% of the reef, and without intervention, another 20% will be damaged within 5 years. Proposal 1: Establish no-anchor zones covering 75% of the reef area. Cost: $180,000. Scientific projections indicate this would protect the remaining healthy coral and allow 30% recovery of damaged areas over 15 years. The Tourism Board estimates this would reduce annual tourism revenue by $1,000,000. Proposal 2: Create a smaller no-anchor zone (40% of reef area) combined with designated safe boat tie-up points at popular diving spots. Cost: $220,000. Scientific projections indicate this would protect the remaining healthy coral and allow 25% recovery of damaged areas over 15 years. Tourism revenue would remain stable. Which proposal BEST meets the committee's requirement to restore coral while staying within their $250,000 budget and minimizing economic impact?
